learningOutline.pre: Get pupils to review their learning in the unit so far by asking them to explain which famous person they most admire. Allow pupils time to discuss their ideas in small groups before sharing.
learningOutline.during: This lesson focuses on Activities 1–4. First complete Activity 1, identifying features of formal/informal emails. Extend Activity 2 by asking pupils to make a plan of an informal email they would write in reply. After completing Activities 3 and 4, ask pupils to modify their rough draft.
learningOutline.post: Ask pupils to work in groups and discuss the easiest and most challenging part of creating a plan. Monitor and make a note of their feedback for future planning.

sow.differentiationStrategy: Allow more proficient pupils to work independently. Support less proficient pupils during Activities 1 and 2 by making them teacher-led. Help with ideas by creating a mind map. Challenge proficient pupils to write a more detailed draft of up to 250 words.

preLesson: Students participate in a brief 'Think-Pair-Share' activity, discussing which famous person they most admire and why, sharing their initial ideas with a partner.
The teacher leads a whole-class discussion, encouraging students to briefly share their famous person and a single reason for their admiration, creating a collaborative mind map on the board.
duringLesson: Students will analyse examples of formal and informal emails, identifying key differences in language and structure.
Students work in pairs to brainstorm ideas and create a plan for an informal email responding to a prompt: 'Imagine you're writing to a friend about a famous person you admire. Who is it and why?'
Students independently begin drafting their informal email response, focusing on clarity, coherence, and appropriate tone.
Students participate in a 'peer review' activity, where they exchange their rough drafts with a partner and provide constructive feedback based on a simple checklist (e.g., clarity, tone, content).
postLesson: Students individually reflect on the planning and drafting process, noting down one thing they found easy and one thing they found challenging.
Students form small groups to discuss their reflections, sharing their challenges and offering potential solutions to one another.
The teacher facilitates a brief whole-class debriefing, summarizing common challenges and offering further guidance.

plan.learningObjective: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to create a structured informal email draft of approximately 150-200 words responding to a prompt about a famous person they admire, demonstrating an understanding of appropriate tone and language.
successCriteria: I can identify the key features of formal and informal emails.
I can plan the content and structure of my informal email response.
I can use informal language and tone appropriately in my email draft.
I can provide a detailed explanation of why I admire a particular famous person.

learningOutline.pre: Activate pupils’ prior knowledge by having them work on Activity 1, first alone and then in pairs. Put pupils in new pairs to create sentences with phrases from the activity.
learningOutline.during: This lesson focuses on Activities 2 and 3. Activity 3 focuses on developing the main skill. An extension of Activity 2 focuses on the complementary skill, where pupils explain their answers and their partner's admirable qualities to new partners.
learningOutline.post: Have a class discussion. Ask pupils which of the listed qualities they find most admirable and why? Discuss other admirable qualities and what they admire most in their friends.

sow.differentiationStrategy: Make a note to follow up with less proficient pupils. To support confident pupils, pause the listening track at selected intervals. Challenge more proficient pupils by asking them to create a list of abstract nouns and decide if they describe good or bad qualities.

preLesson: Students complete Activity 1 individually by matching adjectives describing personal qualities to their definitions.
Students pair up and discuss their answers, then create original sentences using the adjectives.
The teacher facilitates whole-class feedback, clarifying any misunderstandings.
duringLesson: Students listen to a recording (Activity 2) about individuals describing their admirable qualities and complete a gap-fill exercise focusing on identifying those qualities.
Students check their answers in pairs and discuss any discrepancies.

Students complete Activity 3 by brainstorming examples of how the qualities they heard in the recording are demonstrated in real life. (e.g., If they heard about 'patience', they might suggest 'waiting calmly in a long queue').
Students get into new pairs and explain their answers from Activity 2, also mentioning their partner’s admirable qualities based on their interactions so far.
postLesson: The class engages in a whole-class discussion about which of the listed qualities they find most admirable and why.
Students brainstorm other admirable qualities not mentioned in the recording, such as resilience, humility, or creativity.
Students discuss what they admire most in their friends and provide specific examples of how those qualities are demonstrated.

plan.learningObjective: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to identify and describe admirable qualities in themselves and others using appropriate vocabulary related to personal characteristics, and articulate how these qualities are demonstrated in everyday actions.
successCriteria: I can identify at least three admirable qualities in a person's character.
I can use specific vocabulary to describe admirable qualities.
I can explain how these qualities are demonstrated in everyday actions or situations.
I can apply my understanding of admirable qualities to real-life scenarios.

learningOutline.pre: Activate pupils’ prior knowledge by asking questions to elicit responses using either the present simple or present continuous. Ask pupils to explain the difference in usage.
learningOutline.during: This lesson focuses on present simple vs present continuous and relative clauses. Use activities from Student's Book p9 and p11, allowing for pair and group discussions before collecting responses.
learningOutline.post: Ask pupils to review their learning by working in pairs and making their own sentences using relative clauses. Put a list of relative clauses on the board and ask pupils to share their ideas with the class.

sow.differentiationStrategy: Organise talk partners or grouping so that a more proficient pupil can help a less proficient pupil. Challenge more proficient pupils by asking them to write their own paragraph using multiple relative pronouns, including more challenging ones with prepositions.

preLesson: The teacher initiates a class discussion about technology use by asking students about their favourite apps and devices, focusing on how often they use them.
Students share their answers and the teacher writes some of the verbs and nouns used on the board.
The teacher asks students to differentiate between habits (present simple) and what they are doing right now (present continuous) with their devices, using the examples on the board.
duringLesson: Students individually brainstorm a list of 5 things they frequently do with technology (present simple) and 5 things they are currently using technology for or plan to use it for today (present continuous).
Students pair up and share their lists, correcting each other's tense usage as needed.

The teacher displays a list of relative pronouns (who, which, that, whose, where) and provides example sentences on the board related to technology, highlighting the use of relative clauses to add detail.
Students work in groups of four to transform their individual sentences into more complex sentences by adding relative clauses (e.g., 'I use my phone which has a really big screen').
Each group shares some of their improved sentences with the class.
postLesson: Students individually write a short paragraph (5-7 sentences) about their personal relationship with technology, incorporating both present simple/continuous tenses and relative clauses.
Students exchange their paragraphs with a partner and provide constructive feedback, focusing on grammar and clarity.
The teacher facilitates a class discussion, prompting students to share what they learned about their classmates' technology habits and any common challenges they face.
The teacher asks students to think of possible solutions or advice for a person who is excessively addicted to technology (using relative clauses), and students share their ideas with the class.

plan.learningObjective: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to create sentences and a short paragraph about their personal relationship with technology using present simple, present continuous, and relative clauses.
successCriteria: I can accurately use the present simple and present continuous tenses to describe my technology habits.
I can correctly form relative clauses using 'who', 'which', 'that', 'whose', and 'where' to add detail to my sentences.
I can combine sentences with relative clauses to create a coherent paragraph about my relationship with technology.
I can offer suggestions for improvement using relative clauses.

communityData.title: Using formal register - Form 5
communityData.description: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to role-play a formal speaking test scenario, demonstrating appropriate register and language with minimal errors.

learningOutline.pre: Choose an appropriate pre-lesson activity that suits pupils’ needs/interests and that will review language and/or vocabulary.
learningOutline.during: This lesson focuses on speaking activities, emphasizing the use of appropriate register. Pupils discuss the correct register for a speaking test, then role-play as examiner and candidate. At the end of the role play, pupils discuss their feelings about past speaking tests.
learningOutline.post: Ask pupils to review their learning by completing an exit card about the speaking activities: ‘what they were able to do well?’ and ‘what they found particularly challenging?’.

sow.differentiationStrategy: Give new rounds of questions to proficient pairs and provide feedback to pairs that need support, then ask them to repeat their role play. Plan additional speaking activities in case of extra time.

preLesson: The teacher displays pictures of various formal and informal settings (e.g., job interview vs. chatting with friends) and asks students to identify the register used in each scenario.
Students brainstorm words and phrases associated with formal communication and the teacher writes them on the board.
Teacher leads a quick review of common grammatical errors made in speaking tests (e.g., subject-verb agreement, tense usage).
duringLesson: The teacher explains the specific requirements of a formal speaking test, highlighting the importance of register, tone, and grammar.
Students are given a sample speaking test prompt and work in pairs to create a short dialogue using a formal register.
Each pair takes turns role-playing the speaking test, with one student acting as the examiner and the other as the candidate.
After each role-play, the teacher provides constructive feedback on the students' use of formal register, offering suggestions for improvement.
Pairs are given new speaking prompts to repeat the role-play with improved formal register, if they need support with new round of questions.
postLesson: Students complete an exit card reflecting on their role-play, noting one thing they did well and one thing they found challenging regarding formal register.
The teacher leads a brief class discussion about the importance of using formal register in different contexts, emphasizing its relevance for future academic and professional opportunities.
Students share their feelings about the speaking test.

plan.learningObjective: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to role-play a formal speaking test scenario, demonstrating appropriate register and language with minimal errors.
successCriteria: I can identify and use formal greetings and farewells in a speaking test.
I can use appropriate vocabulary and grammar when answering questions in a formal setting.
I can maintain a polite and respectful tone throughout the role-play.
I can evaluate my own and my partner's use of formal register during the role-play.

learningOutline.pre: Activate pupils’ prior knowledge in this lesson by writing on the whiteboard: adoptive family, blended family, extended family, single-parent family and traditional family. Ask pupils to discuss in pairs what they think these terms mean. When ready, share pupils’ ideas as a class. Complete Activity 1, p5.
learningOutline.during: This lesson focuses on Activities 1–3. Activities 1–2 focus on developing the complementary skill. Activity 3 with additional questions focuses on developing the main skill. To achieve the main skill, begin Activity 3 by giving pupils at least three open-ended questions (i.e. Wh questions) that focus on the main points in the text. In order to focus on the complementary skill, extend the speaking activity by asking pupils to explain how they feel about doing household chores.
learningOutline.post: Put pupils in small groups to discuss the topic in the extension activity on the bottom of p10 in the Teacher’s Book. Monitor and help with vocabulary if necessary, but do not interrupt fluency. Make a note of any mistakes to go over with the class after the discussion.

sow.differentiationStrategy: Support can be given to less proficient pupils by providing vocabulary to use in the speaking activity, or sentence starters. Challenge more proficient pupils by asking them to come up with a summary sentence/phrase for each of the four paragraphs.

preLesson: The teacher will write the following terms on the whiteboard: adoptive family, blended family, extended family, single-parent family, and traditional family.
Students will discuss in pairs what they think these terms mean and share their ideas with the class.
Students will complete Activity 1 on page 5 of their textbook.
duringLesson: Students will read Activities 1-3 to understand the text and prepare for a speaking task.
The teacher will ask open-ended questions about the text (e.g., What challenges might blended families face? How can chores be divided fairly in a single-parent family?).
Students will discuss their feelings about doing household chores in pairs, focusing on fairness and responsibility.
Students will brainstorm ideas for a short narrative about a family, considering different family structures and personal experiences.
postLesson: Students will form small groups to discuss the prompt: 'Imagine you are writing a story about a family. What kind of family would it be? What challenges would they face? What would make them unique?' (based on the extension activity on page 10 of the Teacher's Book).
Each student will individually create a short narrative (approximately 150-200 words) about the family they discussed, focusing on their unique challenges and personal connections.
Students will share their narratives with their small groups, focusing on the creative aspects of their story.

plan.learningObjective: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to create a short narrative about a family (real or fictional) that reflects an understanding of diverse family structures and personal experiences.
successCriteria: I can identify and describe different types of family structures (adoptive, blended, extended, single-parent, traditional).
I can express my opinions about household chores and relate them to family dynamics.
I can brainstorm ideas for a narrative that includes realistic characters and settings.
I can write a short narrative reflecting on the theme of 'It's Personal!' with creative flair.
